cluster_relations.rel_desc: Chromium, as an alloying element in stainless steels, contributes to resistance against oxidation.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Subject (typically an alloying element or component) causally contributes to the resistance of a material system against a specified corrosion or degradation mechanism.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Context: chromium in stainless steel alloy matrix

remarks: Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.
Resistance is mediated via stainless steels; not direct chromium surface behavior, but captured as a causal contribution.

qualifiers.ConditionExpression: when present as alloying element in stainless steels

remarks: Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.
Again, resistance is via its role in stainless steels rather than isolated chromium behavior.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: StructureContext: part of mixed austenitic-ferritic phase balance

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Hydrogen Induced Cracking (HIC) is described as a cracking mechanism that occurs in steels, which plausibly includes low alloy steels as a subset.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that a microstructure, damage mechanism, process, or product phase occurs in or is present within a given material or alloy family.

qualifiers.SpatialQualifier: on different planes in the metal / steels; may connect to the metal surface
qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: no externally applied stress is needed for formation of HIC
qualifiers.CausalHint: because of internal pressure resulting from the accumulation of hydrogen
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CrackMechanism: stepwise internal cracks that connect adjacent hydrogen blisters; LinkMechanism: transgranular plastic shear

remarks: Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

Relation added mainly to capture that HIC is a cracking mechanism relevant to steels, with low alloy steel treated as a representative steel family. Semantics somewhat generic; confidence reduced because the text does not explicitly name low alloy steels as HIC-susceptible.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of carbon steels after long-term operation, degrading their mechanical properties.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: A process or condition changes the microstructure of a material or alloy (e.g., phase distribution, morphology, or microstructural constituents).

qualifiers.OperationalConstraint: operation in the 800°F to 1100°F (427°C to 593°C) range
qualifiers.CausalHint: that may cause a loss in strength, ductility, and/or creep resistance
qualifiers.OtherQualifier: DamageType: mechanical property degradation

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization alters the microstructure of 0.5Mo steels during long-term high-temperature operation.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Graphitization corresponds to decomposition of carbide phases into graphite nodules, effectively producing graphite nodules in the steel.

Carbide phases are not an explicit entity; relation framed between graphitization and graphite nodules to preserve transformation context.

cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that two materials or chemicals can serve the same functional role in a given application and may be substituted for one another.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: ApplicationContext: amine treating of hydrocarbon streams for H2S and CO2 removal

remarks: Relation created to capture that these two amine treating chemicals share the same described use; semantics are approximated as an alternative/substitute relation since no explicit comparison wording is given.

cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: CategoryType: stainless steel category

remarks: Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.
Although text just says 'duplex', entity is resolved as duplex stainless steel; relation captures the category membership.

cluster_relations.rel_desc: Duplex stainless steel is a subtype/category within the broader class of stainless steels.
cluster_relations.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a more specific subtype or category within the broader class represented by the object.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a broader class that includes the object as one of its more specific subtypes or categories.
args.justification: The current canonical_rel_name 'is_subtype_of' is inconsistent with the subject/object direction for this instance: 'Stainless Steel' is a broader category and 'duplex stainless steel' is the subtype. To keep predicate semantics consistent with the definition (subject more specific than object), this relation should use a parent-to-child predicate such as 'has_subtype'. The relation class and group remain valid as taxonomic/identity semantics.
args.remark: Normalized to a parent-to-subtype predicate to avoid directional inconsistency with other 'is_subtype_of' uses in the schema.

executed_decisions.canonical_rel_desc: Indicates that the subject is a broader class that includes the object as one of its more specific subtypes or categories.
executed_decisions.justification: The current canonical_rel_name 'is_subtype_of' is inconsistent with the subject/object direction for this instance: 'Stainless Steel' is a broader category and 'duplex stainless steel' is the subtype. To keep predicate semantics consistent with the definition (subject more specific than object), this relation should use a parent-to-child predicate such as 'has_subtype'. The relation class and group remain valid as taxonomic/identity semantics.
executed_decisions.remark: Normalized to a parent-to-subtype predicate to avoid directional inconsistency with other 'is_subtype_of' uses in the schema.
